body:
All deployment options are on the table at this stage, docker could be it as well as building & deploying on AWS instances manually.

Your reply leads me to ask another question, if Cassandra is being phased out why is the docker-zipkin project relying on it? What is the recommended storage backend these days? (I guess the answer is "it depends", I'm just trying to find out which option is going to be the best supported).

Twitter the company isn't using Cassandra anymore, but Zipkin the open source software is using Cassandra a lot (I think Cassandra is regarded as the main storage backend)
Zipkin was originally written at Twitter, but now, the project has been moved out into its own organisation.

cassandra remains the most supported, as it is used in docker, etc. as
Eirik mentioned zipkin is its own thing. Feel free to join us!
https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
FYI twitter doesn't use any of the affected code.
+1 :beers:
:+1: thanks for doing this, I left a NIO comment

PTAL things are adjusted except @clehene valid feedback on env variable naming. Leaving this way to be consistent with how cassandra is being configured. I _really_ want us to do better when we move from working around ostrich to designing our cli interface in #466
completely knackered, but agree this is really bad. please nag on https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin if this becomes critical and still left undone.
going to review-after-commit this one.. feel free to tell me things to follow-up on

Here's a start. I managed to get it working locally today and updated this: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-anormdb

``` bash
$ mysql -uroot -e "create database if not exists zipkin"
$ MYSQL_USER=root ./bin/collector mysql
$ MYSQL_USER=root ./bin/query mysql
$ ./bin/tracegen
...
```

For those watching at home.. the collector can now have kafka enabled. There's configuration options here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/tree/master/zipkin-receiver-kafka

can't wait to see @clehene's end-to-end
awesome! :100:

Only suggestion I have is that it is probably in the wrong repo. Docs for
docker should be in docker-zipkin else we are surely to duplicate efforts.
Regardless, we can link out to this.

Make sense?

> Docs for docker should be in docker-zipkin

:+1:
done
this is pretty much done, right?
zipkin-mongodb and zipkin-hbase aren't, and i'm guessing there are a couple of other spun-out projects that also need love? maybe those should be tracked in a separate issue though.
that reminds me...

there might remain confusion about this, and it's normal for cassandra consumer to define contact points as only ipaddresses and then port separately.

that is "contact point" in cassandra terminology does not include a port.

i guess that confusion couldn't be avoided either as we're also needing to support the existing "zipkin.store.cassandra.dest" flag.

This actually works now

![screen shot 2015-09-06 at 1 44 44 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/64215/9706573/80028a60-549d-11e5-9347-0b2ba6839176.png)
ps eventhough the thrifts were re-organized, they are completely compatible. Here's an example of running master's web against the endpoints.

Finally, the UI is live again! Thanks a lot!
I've been working with the hadoop job, but it's tough to make it work. I'll consider copypasting Cassie into there, just to get something that works....

+1 on this PR!
you're right.. it can get flakey. should we change the scripts to package (not via clean so it is faster) and launch the jar directly?
fwiw.. if ever I run into a problem, I repeat after a `./gradlew clean`
this needs to be reverted once jcenter is back https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin/commit/60ce238de4f9c7bcc4dca5f81df08235b9366c8c
https://bintray.com/openzipkin/maven/zipkin/view has some of our things.. I'll try to do a release

Note, the package used to be https://bintray.com/openzipkin/zipkin/zipkin and is now https://bintray.com/openzipkin/maven/zipkin

Hopefully, the scripts still work and all that's needed is an update to the release doc, with the right url to click for maven central sync.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/RELEASE.md
thanks for the help. only one nit
changed scripts and docs to use the "maven" package instead of the "zipkin" one https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/fdf1bbe9b8209bc6438fa9462f9c8279574bee84
back in business. latest version is 1.6.0
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTRACE-235

This is a breaking change for some people. Some spans they might already have stored will not be readable. I would bump the version in the gradle file too

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-redis/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/redis/RedisStorage.scala#L23

Looks like an issue in the cassandra layer

PS I'm offline until Monday. Anyone else can feel free to look at this,
else I will then.
@jfeltesse-mdsol so I think we still want this to install the schema, even if it is reading from files. (preserving the install=true contract). I'll add work on your commit to do that.
ps I think these should be the same file. the only reason the indexes weren't in the default formerly was that index syntax isn't portable.
actually I see what you mean. mysql needs a separate step to install the database anyway, and probably prod usage wouldn't want to give it access to change its schema.
Thanks for the start! I added polish on the other.
cool stuff! :100:
:ok_woman:
I probably wouldn't notice any deep issues in this (no knowledge of the related tech), but FWIW, it looks good to me.

To whom it may concern. I looked into resurrecting this. The problem is that there is very little test coverage to say what "should" happen. For example, the tests are trivial and rely mostly on whatever algebird is supposed to do. Best first step would be to backfill tests for the working implementation (anormdb and/or zipkin-hbase), then try to make a cassandra impl that passes those tests.
See also [Working Effectively With Legacy Code](http://objectmentor.com/resources/articles/WorkingEffectivelyWithLegacyCode.pdf) <_<

I'm using the following workaround to make this work on my fork:
- https://github.com/betable/zipkin/commit/4bd522fc7d81d8c30877b3817c9e1095874743f9

It goes back to using the value set in the ZipkinServerBuilder.

A working commit that addresses this

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/709
love it except for the stats. if we want, we can start a microbenchmark around compression time, otherwise, I'd leave it out.

Looks like this was partially implemented as environment variables in collector like so

``` scala
val serverPort = sys.env.get("COLLECTOR_PORT").getOrElse("9410").toInt
val adminPort = sys.env.get("COLLECTOR_ADMIN_PORT").getOrElse("9900").toInt
```

Mind if I just implement that convention with COLLECTOR, QUERY, WEB?

Yeah I like that idea, that is how I am configuring our collector service. I have the following in my query.scala config (which works with the above patch):

``` scala
val serverPort = sys.env.get("QUERY_PORT").getOrElse("9411").toInt
val adminPort = sys.env.get("QUERY_ADMIN_PORT").getOrElse("9901").toInt



QueryServiceBuilder(
  storeBuilder,
  serverBuilder = ZipkinServerBuilder(serverPort, adminPort).loggers(List(loggerFactory))
)
```

I basically copied what collector was doing in its config.
@wadey this one's for you

PS here's a working docker-compose pointing to amazon RDS. cc @abesto

``` yaml
collector:
  image: quay.io/openzipkin/zipkin-collector:1.7.1
  environment:
    - MYSQL_HOST=zipkin.lalalalalalala.us-west-2.rds.amazonaws.com
    - MYSQL_USER=zipkin
    - MYSQL_PASS=NOT_TELLING
  entrypoint: /bin/sh
  command: -c "java -cp ${ANORMPATCH_CLASSPATH}:/zipkin/zipkin-collector.jar com.twitter.zipkin.collector.Main -f /collector-mysql.scala"
  expose:
    - 9410
  ports:
    - 9410:9410
    - 9900:9900
query:
  image: quay.io/openzipkin/zipkin-query:1.7.1
  environment:
    - MYSQL_HOST=zipkin.lalalalalalala.us-west-2.rds.amazonaws.com
    - MYSQL_USER=zipkin
    - MYSQL_PASS=NOT_TELLING
  entrypoint: /bin/sh
  command: -c "java -cp ${ANORMPATCH_CLASSPATH}:/zipkin/zipkin-query.jar com.twitter.zipkin.query.Main -f /query-mysql.scala"
  expose:
    - 9411
  ports:
    - 9411:9411
    - 9901:9901
web:
  image: quay.io/openzipkin/zipkin-web:1.7.1
  links:
    - query
  ports:
    - 8080:8080
    - 9990:9990
```
cc @kristofa @yurishkuro
Timing checks could be moved to unit tests that we can run whenever we need to benchmark changes.
Will this break backwards-compatibility for clients that send traces that are not snappy-encoded?

May related to this issue: https://datastax-oss.atlassian.net/browse/JAVA-852?jql=text%20~%20%22tokens%20null%22 .

I notice that zipkin has used the official client instead of twitter/cassie when moved to zipkin.
Yup; Zipkin moved to the official client since Cassie is abandoned/deprecated/gone.
Yes, it does. Same as the cassandra change a few commits ago which removed snappy compression on the client side
Snappy compression with the compact protocol was merged to master
PS this merged after a minor version increment
I agree, except not as unit tests, but microbenchmarks (JMH).

ok much cleaner impl now, based on advise from @kristofa and feedback from @yurishkuro 

zipkin traces now appear as services "zipkin-web" and "zipkin-query"

Tested with:

``` bash
$ bin/collector
$ SCRIBE_PORT=9410 bin/query
$ SCRIBE_PORT=9410 bin/web
$ curl -s localhost:8080/api/services
# now see services pop up!
$ curl -s localhost:8080/api/services
["zipkin-query","zipkin-web"]
```
I was not familiar with the `DefaultTracer.self` approach. Using the `NullTracer` is also better than having sample rate = 0.  :+1:
cc @dsyer @jamescway @spencergibb @jfeltesse-mdsol I'm not sure this is actually causing problems in real life, but will look into it later.

Thanks @adriancole!

But your patch is actually incomplete and doesn't change the query port (try to change QUERY_PORT and see what happens). You need something like the changes I have for QueryServiceBuilder and ZipkinQueryServerFactory here:
- https://github.com/betable/zipkin/commit/4bd522fc7d81d8c30877b3817c9e1095874743f9
Yep you're right! https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/714/files
tested with local anormdb both dev and mysql mode. no more log clutter, but spans still log.

This is timing out again.. when it does, here's the command to sign manually. Then, go to bintray and publish the artifacts.

``` bash
# substitute whatever version instead of 1.8.1
$ curl https://$USER:$BINTRAY_API_KEY@api.bintray.com/gpg/openzipkin/maven/zipkin/versions/1.8.1 -XPOST
```
neat idea
I guess all travis wants is some output..?
looks like it is worth a shot. thanks!
Note this bumps version
cc @spencergibb @wadey @kristofa

Here's some feedback on this topic.

From @kristofa 

```
About duration for an annotation. This can be used to track duration of certain parts of your app. For example I had the idea of submitting an annotation with duration for measuring Json serialisation time. The annotation is displayed in Zipkin-web on the Span at its time stamp. Unfortunately the actual duration is not displayed in Zipkin-web. That's why in Brave I added the duration, if specified, to the annotation name.
```

From @yurishkuro 

```
I had a meeting today with our mobile team, they are interested in using Zipkin tracing for measuring timing of various functions within the app, ranging across time to open a controller, time to resolve DNS, time to call a service, etc. Not all of these use cases fit directly into Zipkin RPC model, some are more like stages of an operation rather than sub-spans. An annotation's duration might be an interesting one to use.
```

I'd suggest that if folks want to use duration, then let's evaluate it against real use cases. You may find overlaps with sub-service spans, normal metrics, or even find that duration would work better on BinaryAnnotation (which has both key and value). Duration certainly does seem handy, but we do need to face the facts that this is a broken and confusing part of zipkin.

Leaving something handy, but broke in zipkin is worse than removing it, IMHO. Decent use cases, tests and documentation would be the only way we could prevent repeating status quo, which is broken and has led to curious implementations and bugs in an unusable feature.

Thinking about alternatives here, too. One thing we've tossed around is having a [common data model for annotations](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pxZ5NQHftJzhlCIT4vMfOT6QT_StikaoDc_NCdfesoA/edit). Let's take the case of GC, for example.

GC happens to be something that isn't caused by the span, it is metadata present, which could help explain timing, but it could be far longer than the span itself and hint at a visualization concern. Nevertheless, let's consider how we might do this.

As opposed to an `Annotation`, which has a timestamp, and a name, but no value like this:

```
value=Gc(10,0.PSScavenge,2015-09-17 12:57:12 +0000,525.milliseconds+970.microseconds)
duration=525970
```

What if this were a `BinaryAnnotation` which doesn't have a timestamp, but does have a value:

```
key=gc.durationMillis
type=I32
value=525970
```

Speaking with @dsyer here, this seems to make more sense, as you can query against it, and its namespace explains itself. Moreover, it is ancillary information to explain the span (ex. it isn't a sub-span, or an activity directly caused by it)

Merging as I think @kristofa and @yurishkuro are on board:

@kristofa 

```
Yes. I agree. You can also track such metrics with a regular monitoring system and graph them, calculate percentiles etc.
```

@yurishkuro

```
+1 for local span. As alternative to duration, I think it's more structured, and can be rendered nicer. ... kill the durations, kill zem all
```
@mzagar @eirslett either of you have some cycles to help with this by chance?
See also https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HTRACE-260
cc @dsyer @jfeltesse-mdsol
Aah, we need to encodeURIComponent() it in the JavaScript layer, I guess,
I've experienced the same thing.

I don't think that is the problem. When we are splitting, it should split only by the first `=` and the rest of them should stay as in, in the value. The limitation of this is `=` should not be in the key, but that is not a deal breaker.

To answer your question, there's no way to do this from the server side.
The sting matching is exact both on key and value.

It might be possible to filter in the JavaScript though.

I think it would have to happen on the server side (unless you want 10 TB of trace data sent to the browser so it can be filtered there)
Actually it would have to happen in the database query - I have no idea how that should work... The easiest thing would probably be to write an Elasticsearch backend, which is much more powerful when it comes to searching.

I think you might misunderstand me, I'm tossing out a workaround that
doesn't imply teaching storage systems regex or similar.

We should still keep good query in mind, and i think ES is something we
should support, too. Let's discuss this at the working group? Surely others
have this in mind, too.

About the workaround, which might still be invalid even how I see it.

The current api filters with a limit, right? If you search for traces and
are already filtering by service, name, timestamp, key.. I don't know what
number you'd have to place into limit to get 10GB of data back. ;)

Let's say you had a good query, just fuzzy on one point. Ex you already
have http response code in there and you chose to return 100 results whose
key are X but value Y isn't something you are sure about.

A workaround could be to allow a regex refine client-side which could
filter the results you asked for. This is a workaround, but easier than
trying to get all impls to do full text search ;)
ps here's what I was talking about wrt a real solution.. feel free to add desires here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/13KPpzl4WkawrLYddN6rtqDpuqSs0Yw1vszgWORyrH1o/edit
LGTM. thanks!
Still works! i.e. the darkness of the line corresponds to call count.
